raw_text:
```json
{
  "paper_metadata": {
    "title": "The Difference that Cash and In-Kind Grants Make to Microenterprise Growth: Evidence from a Randomized Experiment in Ghana",
    "matches_expected_title": "YES"
  },
  "program_information": {
    "program_name": "Cash and In-Kind Grants for Microenterprises",
    "country": "Ghana",
    "region": "Urban",
    "target_population": "Male- and female-owned microenterprises with no paid employees"
  },
  "intervention_components": {
    "component_a_cash_support": {
      "component_a_present": true,
      "cash_support_type": "cash grants",
      "cash_amount": "150 Ghanaian cedis (approximately $120 at the time of the baseline)",
      "cash_frequency": "one-time",
      "is_loan_or_credit": "NO",
      "cash_evidence_citation": "Firms which completed the first two survey rounds were randomly allocated into three groups: a control group of 396 firms, a treatment group of 198 firms which would receive 150 Ghanaian cedis (approximately US$120 at the time of the baseline) in cash which they could use for any purpose."
    },
    "component_b_assets": {
      "component_b_present": true,
      "assets_provided": [
        "equipment",
        "materials",
        "inventories (e.g., beauty care products, electronic goods, alcohol, food)",
        "raw materials (e.g., wood, sandpaper, cloth, oil, cooking ingredients, shampoos)",
        "sewing and knitting machines",
        "hair dryers",
        "carpentry equipment"
      ],
      "direct_provision": "YES",
      "assets_evidence_citation": "In the case of the in-kind treatment, the equipment or materials were selected by the firm owner and purchased directly by our research assistants with the owner. The majority of this was in the form of inventories to sell (e.g. beauty care products, electronic goods, alcohol, food) and raw materials (e.g. wood, sandpaper, cloth, oil and other cooking ingredients, shampoos and supplies for beauty salon use). Only 24 percent of those receiving the in-kind treatment elected to buy physical equipment, with the most common equipment purchased being sewing and knitting machines by tailors, hair dryers by owners of beauty salons, and drills and other carpentry equipment by firms in woodwork."
    }
  },
  "study_characteristics": {
    "outcomes_measured": [
      "business profits",
      "capital stock",
      "household consumption",
      "business investment"
    ],
    "outcomes_evidence_citation": "We find that cash grants tend to be spent on household consumption or transferred out of the house, especially when given to women whose businesses were small to begin with. | A one-time in-kind grant of 150 cedis is estimated to increase monthly profits by 37-39 cedis for both males and females, a large average return on this grant. | Figure 4: Post-treatment CDFs of Capital Stock for Females by Treatment Group.",
    "study_design": "Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)",
    "design_evidence_citation": "Firms which completed the first two survey rounds were randomly allocated into three groups: a control group of 396 firms, a treatment group of 198 firms which would receive 150 Ghanaian cedis (approximately US$120 at the time of the baseline) in cash which they could use for any purpose, and a treatment group of 198 firms which would receive 150 cedis in equipment, materials, or inventories for their business.",
    "is_review_or_policy_analysis": false,
    "publication_year": null,
    "study_conducted_year": "2009",
    "sample_size": 793,
    "completed": true
  },
  "bonus_information": {
    "has_qualitative_components": false,
    "qualitative_methods": [],
    "qualitative_evidence_citation": null,
    "has_cost_data": false,
    "cost_mentions": null,
    "cost_evidence_citation": null
  },
  "evidence_citations": {
    "program_name_citation": "We randomly gave cash and in-kind grants to male-and female-owned microenterprises in urban Ghana.",
    "country_citation": "We randomly gave cash and in-kind grants to male-and female-owned microenterprises in urban Ghana.",
    "target_population_citation": "A sample of both female and male microenterprise owners who had no paid employees at the time of the baseline survey were randomly allocated into treatment and control groups."
  }
}
```
